Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7929 We are aware that there is a deeper sense of community spirit, a sense of being needed, a powerful instinct to stand together in our country's darkest hour, a personal feeling of sharing in a great effort, of belonging, of having a real social purpose. One aspect of suicide then, leaving aside those cases of the mentally ill, is a deadly crisis in one's emotional life. It is the lack of any perception by a vulnerable person of any sense of feeling valued or feeling needed or feeling worthwhile. This does not necessarily mean that such a person is not loved or not needed or not worthwhile but that they do not perceive that they are. When such a perception is coupled with a problem in their lives which they are unable to solve because of poor problem solving skills, or they are unable to share because of poor communication links, they find themselves alone, isolated and hopeless, and in terrible danger. We all know how to create a loving and loved, well-adjusted adult human being. It takes a loving and nurturing environment which allows the infant human being to grow in selfesteem and self-confidence, secure in the knowledge of who they are and where they fit within their families and within their neighbourhood. It is the natural consequence of growing up in a loving family network. I do not assume to define a family because they are like rainbowsthey come in many colours. But, within a nurturing family, a strong sense of belonging and contented happiness grows within the self of the infant from the first days of its life. Babies just do not survive without love, affection and care. In my electorate of Hughes one of our church groups carried out a survey on the feelings of local young people in an attempt to find out how to assist them. To the question, 'Do you consider that you live in a loving, caring home environment?' an unexpected 67 per cent said, 'No.' I am sure their parents would be shocked because these children come from solid, middle-class families where hard working mums and dads are endeavouring to provide the benefits of life for their offspring, and whose love for their children is their singular reason for working so hard. The problem is that the children do not perceive the strength and security of this love, and this signals to me that we have some very serious problems in the way and effectiveness by which we communicate the strength of our love to our children. One leading consultant child psychiatrist told me that he believed human beings need at least four seven-second hugs a day. Hugs say a lot, especially in the uncertain world of the adolescent. Hugs actually say, wordlessly but very powerfully, 'I value you.' Loving hugs are the greatest expression of emotional reinforcement and personal affirmation that we can give our children: they cost nothing but time. But teenagers are not cute and cuddly and it seems very few receive hugs. Often a self-held perception of lack of love and self-esteem leads a young person into alcohol and substance abuse because a lack of love means a lack of understanding, which helps create the sense of isolation, which leaves a void within the heart which fills with pain. At the seminar, Professor Kosky raised the issue of feelings as a very important aspect of youth suicide. He said: Suicide is more than just a feeling. You may feel hopeless and have this terrible feeling that things are not going well and that maybe there is no hope, but the thoughts that come to you about wanting to kill yourself because you cannot deal with these factors are also critically important. He then said: If these thoughts turn into the action of self destruction, they become a possible tragedy. So we should not separate feelings but should look at issues in a more holistic fashion ... in terms of thoughts, feelings and actions. 7930 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 There are countless events which could tum those thoughts into actiqns of self-destruction. There is one which I would like to draw to the notice of the House, and that is the undocumented impact of dark, negative and violent lyrics heard in some of the heavy metal type music which is on the market and which is listened to by our children. Let me refer to an article in Family Forum of April 1997 entitled 'Pop music and the death of culture'. It states: Modern music has made some very radical changes in the past few decades. In 1953 the number one song was 'How much is that doggie in the window?' and ten years later the Beatles were singing 'I wanna hold your hand'. Things quickly declined thereafter, however. Songs by the Rolling Stones such as 'Lets spend the night together' led to more graphic ones. One album entitled Her satanic majesty's request contained songs like 'Sympathy for the devil'. Occult and satanic things proliferated as bands like Black Sabbath and Kiss burst onto the scene. Today gangsta rap features themes of rape and violence, well oiled with a torrent of profanity. One rap album used the 'F' word 293 times. Bad language is often more than matched by bad themes. One album by Ice-T called Body count features songs about killing cops and raping women. Death metal groups like Cannibal Corpse, Nine Inch Nails and Slayer dish up grisly tales of violence and death. Consider a few titles from Cannibal Corpse's albums called Crucifixion and Anti-Christ Superstar. Manson, an ordained minister in Anton Levy's Church of Satan delights in promoting murder, suicide and hatred of religion. Band members wear a T-shirt saying, 'Kill your parents'. Consider a few lines from various songs in Anti-Christ Superstar, which reads, 'You can kill yourself now because you are dead in my mind.' These songs of nihilism and hate are certainly a far cry from the kind of popular music of few decades ago. Professor Kosky's warning of the danger of thoughts turning into action can all too easily tum into an icy reality. There is a tow truck driver in my area who has had the terrible job of collecting motor vehicles which have been used by young male suicide victims. On one occasion he reported back to his boss, a personal friend of mine, that when he pressed the button on the cassette deck, out blasted at full volume heavy metal type music with messages of death and hate. He also went on to say that this was not the first time he found this kind of death music in such motor vehicles. It is difficult to believe that there is not a connection. Suicide is a complex and deadly confluence of circumstance and negative thoughts in the life of a young person. When it is understood, as research shows, that children listen to music over 30 per cent of the waking hours, the danger of negative and destructive thoughts turning into tragic action gets closer to becoming a tragic reality. Such violent, hateful, nihilist and doom laden music is freely available for our children to hear. Added to alcohol and drug abuse, it is a deadly cocktail. It is worth observing that illicit drugs appeared in any quantity on the Australian scene in the early 1960s, as did the beginnings of violent and hateful messages of death and destruction in our children's music. It was about this time that our suicide rate began to climb tragically. I strongly urge our government to seriously and urgently investigate the lack of effective regulation in the music industry. This will at least protect our young people from one source of destructive negativity and hate. It is up to us to continue to research this complex issue and take positive action when we do find a situation which demands our attention. As the elected members of parliament, we are the only Australians who can act to stem the importation of such music for the protection of our young people. To do nothing would be a gross abdication of our responsibility to those young Australians who, because of other circumstances in their lives, are vulnerable and are at risk that their negative thoughts turning into the action of selfThursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7931 destruction as illustrated by Professor Kosky. I strongly commend the recommendations of this report to the House. Mr SA WFORD (Port Adelaide) (12.12 p.m.)-Other than acknowledging and recognising the importance of the aspects of youth suicide summary report as further beginning a process in this country to address the appalling statistics of youth suicide, I found the report somewhat disappointing. Let me qualify that. I am appreciative of the fact that the seminar was just one day and that for personal reasons, I was unable to be there. Be that as it may, my disappointment is that only one major point, out of at least the four that are required, was identified and that was the national inquiry. For me, it simply reinforced the view I have held for many years now that, when children are concerned, this parliament is as ignorant as most other influential groups in this country. I will provide evidence to support that perhaps unpopular and minority contention a little later in my speech. I do not intend to be perceived as deliberately provocative. This issue is far too important for that. I simply believe that the direction indicated by the seminar does not go far enough. No-one is the fount of all wisdom, and I am no exception, yet I do not believe I am wrong and I am yet to be convinced that is the case. The summary report correctly indicated that the rates of suicide per 100,000 of population show that, since the 1960s, the rate of young male suicide has almost trebled and the rate of young female suicide has doubled. The report also indicated that, for young males between 1979 and 1995, there has been a fivefold increase in deaths from hanging. The report also acknowledged the multitude of complexities that impact upon the circumstances that lead to youth suicide. But what it did not do was explain and identify the circumstances happening in this country affecting children and adolescents in the 1960s, the 1970s and the 1980s. The report stated that, for young males in Australia between 1979 and 1995, there had been a fivefold increase in deaths arising from hanging. The question that needs to be asked is: what circumstances in this country during this period changed that may have directly or indirectly contributed to feelings of depression, isolation and so on? In 1979, I was a principal of a primary school in Adelaide with about 900 students. I mark this particular year very clearly because in South Australia this was the beginning of the severe decline in the value South Australian society placed on the care and education of children, particularly young children. I soon became very aware that this was not just a South Australian problem. It was an Australian problem, an English speaking world problem and, finally, a developed world problem. There is a given, in my view, in the care and education of children, that is steadily but ever increasingly being devalued in Australia and elsewhere in the world. That given is as follows: that between the ages of seven and 11, the quality of schooling is the most significant determinant of the future success of an individual. It is more important than gender, socioeconomic status, ethnic background or religion, which compared to quality schooling have received far greater priority than they deserve. The London Educational Authority after a four-year longitudinal study, one of the few ever done with children in primary schools, concluded exactly this in 1986. But state governments throughout Australia have ignored that given for the past 20 years. The age group five to 15 are the forgotten people in Australian society. The allocation of resources to this group that actually goes to supporting young people on the ground has seriously deteriorated over the last 20 years. 7932 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 Some will point to increases in funding. But I tell you, precious little of that funding went to kids themselves. The year 1979 saw the beginning of a 'Primary means first' campaign in South Australia to increase resource allocation to primary schools. It failed. In the early 1980s, another campaign entitled 'Into the nineties' commenced and received overwhelming support from schools and parents. Similar campaigns occurred in Tasmania. That campaign and the individuals who drove it, a group of 12 primary principals, was white-anted and discredited by no less than the education bureaucracy and the Secondary Principals Association, who, like some powerful individuals in the teachers union, TAFE and university, saw it as a threat to their favourite resource allocation and fought it tooth and nail. However, this campaign had some success in that the bureaucracy was forced to announce a primary review. Schools, however, are still waiting 10 years on for any substantive implementation of those recommendations. The important point I make here is that advocacy for young people five to 12 disappeared. The separate bureaucracies for early childhood and primary education were dissolved. Individual after individual at a senior level who argued for a fair go for primary aged school kids was given redundancy, retirement or simply chose another occupation. Advocacy for young people aged five to 12 was gone. Can anyone in this house point to a group in Australia that effectively represents the needs of children aged five to 12? There is none. That is a major problem that needs to be addressed. It requires national leadership that up to the present time has gone missing. At the national level, it requires a ministry for children and youth affairs, a point made to this parliament several years ago by the member for La Trobe( Mr Charles) and myself. I have already stated that educational leadership went missing. Political leadership has gone missing too, but it is even more widespread than that. The churches ignored the needs of young children. They were more concerned with dwindling membership, widespread child abuse which was coming to public attention at an alarming rate and looking after their particular sectoral interests. Mainstream structural and resource problems were just overlooked. The unions ignored the needs of young children. Like the churches, they were too preoccupied with dwindling membership, as well as union amalgamations and rightly preserving the jobs of their members. They did not see children five to 12 in their ballpark of interest. The welfare sector forgot the link between the mainstream young and the special groups of adolescents and young adults they tried to represent. The needs of the very young were just ignored. The business sector, which had seldom shown any interest in the very young, simply continued their merry blind way on to what was going on all round them. The women's movement made us all aware of the legitimate needs of women. It failed miserably in recognising the needs of children aged five to 12. Ethnic and indigenous leaders, to the best of my knowledge, made little or no attempt to represent the five to 12 age cohort of children. Their commitment was on other fundamental and, for them, crucial issues. The green movement forgot about the needs of young people, even though these same young people greatly assisted their propaganda. The list of non-concern goes on. I state this not to slam these groups, most of whom were involved, in a period of great change, in fundamental and crucial issues highly important in our time. I simply point to the reality that, in addressing fundamental issues of change, there was no time and no energy for kids. Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7933 In the 1980s, we saw a phenomenal growth in child care, recognising the increasing need for women to enter the work force. Instead of calling it parent respite, which it is, we called it child care. NowI defy anyone in this house to say that the rationale for this was the care of children; it was not. The rationale was to allow parents the opportunity to work and there is nothing intrinsically wrong with that. It makes good economic sense. Whether it makes good social sense for children is somewhat debatable. But again, to take the year 1979 as a starting point, other phenomena were occurring in this country. Unemployment was beginning to become chronic and endemic, and settling around a 10 per cent figure to which orthodox economics could do and would do nothing. As unemployment became entrenched and youth unemployment soared to around 40 per cent and higher in rural and regional Australia, another phenomenon was taking place. As people were getting out of work, overtime in this country soared to 20 million hours a year. That is the equivalent of 500,000 forty-hour a week jobs, from 1978. Note the time scale. For the 150 years prior to 1979, working hours in the English-speaking world decreased and decreased, yet in 1979, for the first time, the graph for working hours goes the other way. Overtime for males increased by 80 per cent and for females there was a 100 per cent increase. At exactly the same time, effective resources for primary schools were being reduced. Parent opportunities to be with their children were also greatly reduced. As more and more parents placed children in child care, parents became less involved in school and community activities, tired by long working hours, depressed by job insecurity. The other group in our community, teachers, who spend as much time with children, were being demoralised by what was occurring in primary education. Children were becoming more and more isolated. The two groups they relied on so heavily, parents and teachers, became preoccupied with their own very real problems. Marriage breakdowns, drug and alcohol abuse, violence and all the other negative issues of today's society all contribute to the isolation of children. Let us not forget the media's role in this. A Sydney study a few years ago recognised that up to 96 per cent of the print media's depiction of our children was negative, and theprecious little-positive depiction of children is not too flash either: pretty young girls, handsome young boys, presenting mostly non-achievable roles for other young people. Cute, but of no substance whatsoever. Yet we are confronted with an ever-increasing crisis with young people in Australian society. All of us are being shown as being quite impotent in dealing with the problem. Young people do not just commit suicide. It is a culmination of years of neglect, wrong diagnosis, wrong emphasis, wrong solutions, and lack of political will and community will, that makes particular young people just end it all. The report correctly identified the dearth of data concerning young people. This is another indication of neglect and wrong emphasis. I have addressed thus far a failure in relationships with children by parents, teachers and interest groups in Australia, including government, and also the failure of an effective advocacy group for children in the age group five to 12. I would like to continue that theme of failure to relate to young people as it impacts on the age group 15 to 19. Rightly or wrongly, we all describe each other by occupation. Young people are no different. Yet dramatic change has impacted upon the opportunities to get a job. The teenage labour market has collapsed. Technology, especially in financial institutions, has removed entry level jobs for young people. Downsizing, outsizing and outsourcing, in both the public and the private sector, have removed entry level jobs for young children, young people. It is short-sighted policy but it is reality. Young people are more adversely affected by those changes than any other group. 7934 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 When young people are in the transition from 15 to 19 years of age, three institutions have a large impact upon them-schools, training providers, in which I include universities, and employers, both private and public. Do schools have a strong relationship with training providers and business or government? Do training providers have a strong relationship with schools and business or government? Does business or government have a strong relationship with schools or training providers? We all know what the answer is. It is a resounding no. The three groups in the real world have no real knowledge of each other. The dialogue that does occur between these three groups is noted for its infrequency and for the predictability that each one of the institutions will denigrate the other two. That is not particularly helpful to young people. One has only to talk to young people themselves who have sent off numerous applications for jobs, only to be rejected, to know the distress that causes. Government, business, training providers and schools can no longer operate in isolation from each other and expect young people to survive and this country to have a positive future. Children and young people need consistency-it is a basic human need. It is my experience with children that, whether their parents relate to them strictly-spare the rod and spoil the child-whether it is by family consensus or whether it is completely laissez-faire, the child is always well adjusted when the message they receive from their parents and teachers is totally consistent and is communicated to the child. It is inconsistency and lack of communication that destroys children's modes of behaviour. It is no different if these children see the same inconsistencies coming from schools, training providers, business or government. The report acknowledges that fatal trauma of young people is higher than the quoted figures. What surprises me is that the figures are not substantially higher, given what young people have been exposed to in our society over the last 20 years. The setting up of a national inquiry will assist the database so sadly and irresponsibly missing. But this tragedy of youth suicide needs much more than that. In brief, three other matters need to be addressed. One is advocacy, one is resources and one is effective communication between groups that have an impact on children and youth. Firstly, the advocacy issue could be begun by the setting up of a ministry of children's and youth affairs at the national level and taking seriously not just youth suicide but all the problems confronting youth and children. We have never done this in this country. Secondly, the resources issue could begin to be effectively addressed again by national leadership, placing much needed accountability on state governments for the negligence-and village hall mentality on many occasions-regarding children's and youth affairs, particularly the issue of resource allocations that actually find their way into the school to benefit children. Thirdly, all groups seeking funding from government would have one other criterion added to that agenda of ethnicity, the disabled, and so on. That criterion should be children and youth. What are they doing? In conclusion, I wish to acknowledge the important work of the standing committee in making a further beginning on this tragic issue. Clearly, I am perhaps on a different wavelength to most-whether that is the correct wavelength, perhaps only time will tell. I thank members for their attention. the member for Port Adelaide( Mr Sawford), and share his concerns about youth. I also wish to highlight what I consider the critical element missing today for young people between the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs West (Bowman) (12.28 P.m.)
theText: I commend the comments of the previous speaker,Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7935 ages of five to 12 and 15 to 19. I see this essentially as a time factor. Parents are no longer willing to spend the time with their youngsters. The opportunity for child care is readily available. But the genuine need for nurturing is still there for the children to share their ideas, for parents to be there to listen, and for children to have the opportunity to talk and to have taken seriously what their place and space is. I met some young people at the recent youth forum conducted in Canberra and it was interesting that these 18and 19-year-olds identified the need for parenting courses as a necessity for parents to have a mature approach to raising children. This is something that I feel we need to identify. Coming out of the mouths of babes, as one of a more mature age would suggest, is the identification of the flaws in perhaps their relationships with their own parents or the flaws they can see in other people's relationships. This is one of the critical pieces of information that has been received relating to this report on youth suicide. The identifiable causes, or the conditions that preceded a suicide, were often the lack of time-or the lack of effort-given by parents towards recognising the child's cry for help. I am pleased today to have the opportunity to speak to the report, Aspects of youth suicide, although its contents are very disturbing. Before talking about the issues contained within the report, I would like to congratulate the committee secretariat and my fellow committee members for the work that they have put into this document. This report should shock all Australians. Suicide, particularly where it concerns our youth, is a subject many would prefer not to talk about. It is a distressing issue and one which, all too often, gets pushed aside: it is put in the too-hard basket. But we are forced to face the realities of life at this time. Youth suicide is a reality. No-one in this house could deny that the current rate of youth suicide in Australia is unacceptably high. If just one person took their own life per year, that rate would be too high. We live in stressful times. There appears to be more pressure on our young to succeed, both at school and in the workplace. There are also more social demands on the youth of today, and the recent concerns over heroin trials and the easy availability of drugs within our community are ringing alarm bells for each and every one of us. The problem is coming closer every day, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is probably someone within your own personal experience who has either attempted to commit-or has succeeded in committing-suicide, who has had available to them drugs or illegal substances, including alcohol and other abuse substances. There are other options for our young, but these are not highlighted as much as the negative aspects of suicide and drug abuse are. Governments need all the help they can. They need advice, realistic advice. They need first hand knowledge from people who have experienced these critical times in life and survived. It is the survivors who can mentor and assist others in the crisis that they are facing at this particular time. Quite frankly, what we found was that youth did not have anywhere to go. Often the peers knew of a child's attempt, and the uncanny disappointment, frustration or depression that was the critical factor, in many cases, that led to suicide. The report goes some way to addressing the needs of our young. It pinpoints the major factors that influence our young and suggests ways in which this and succeeding governments should deal with the problem. I am pleased to say that there are helpful associations out there. Community groups are willing to link and network and assist in the prevention of suicide. 7936 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 The Minister for Family Services( Mrs Moylan) recently launched the Lifeline Australia youth suicide prevention project. This service, which has received $3 million in funding, will extend the range and availability of telephone counselling services to youth. Youth need to share their concerns with someone who is easily contactable. If parents, carers, family members or peers are not there, that telephone link is essential. There are other measures and programs being introduced, totalling $31 million over the next three years. They include $6 million to the states and territories to improve access to counselling services in rural and remote areas, because this was where the need was seen to be critical, as more youth suicides occur in rural and remote areas. There will be $3 million to provide programs for parents-and I really feel that is probably not enough. Parents are everywhere, and they need to be able to access those facilities when they are facing troubled times, depression and financial concerns. So that they do not need to tum to drug or substances to ease the pain, they need friendly advice and assistance. There is $2 million for education and training of health professionals. Recognising the symptoms of depression is critical. If a child presents itself to a GP, which is not always the case because they are usually accompanied by a parent, they may not be willing to express their innermost feelings and the doctor may not be able to identify depression as the cause. However, other health professionals and counsellors in schools should be able to pick up those critical points where a child is suffering, and suffering in silence. There is $1 million for research into childhood mental health and factors which lead to adolescent suicide and attempted suicide. While young adolescent males are the most successful at youth suicide, it is disturbing to find that young girls attempt suicide at a much higher rate. This cry for help needs to be identified and assistance needs to be there at that time. On top of that funding, there is $19 million for the national youth suicide strategy. This includes the Here for Life program initiated by the former administration. The work and activities of that program have created a very positive community support network in areas where it is established. I am aware of one that is being established and is working very well in the Logan area. The networking of community workers is coordinated through the Royal Australian Society of General Practitioners. It has made significant progress towards bridging the gap between informed and trusted GPs and local youth so they can access and communicate with them through their personal interests. There is the opportunity for GPs to go in and talk about current issues. Where young people might not be able to talk about it with their parents if they are not there, they have the time allocated during their school routine to talk about critical issues. They might sound silly-I remember being asked for questions when I was at school and we had to write them down so as to remain anonymous. Quite frankly, some of the answers we got from our adults, who were not GPs, trivialised or did not really listen to our concerns. But I am assured that this program is critically listening and answering the needs of those youth in that situation. I am hopeful that the benefits and expertise of this program can be transferred and translated into my electorate through the Redlands Youth Network. The network has built up a strong support base for many young people in need of help in the area. They have introduced a wide range of programs to assist these people. The group also runs activities, particularly during school holiday periods, to give the youth something constructive to do with their time and not Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7937 give them time to get into trouble. The Redlands Youth Network has the full support of the local council and I have supported their activities in the past. This government will continue to support such groups. In an effort to overcome the problems confronting our youth, we will endeavour to proceed and succeed. However, it is one thing for these programs to be set up. What we as federal members need to be doing is telling our constituents and health professionals what is available. All the money in the world is no good to the 18-year-old in my electorate, or in other electorates around the country, who has been cut off and isolated from society. How is he to know what programs the government has put into place? Who he can call? Where he can call? He or she is too busy searching through the bins at the back of Woolworths trying to find a feed for the night. I was given an offer recently by my local ambulance drivers to join them one night on a tour of the electorate so that I could see what they see. I will be taking them up on the offer, but I can say that what I have already heard about the homeless youth in my local retail shopping centre is disturbing. Having realised this was a major concern, I have met with the Wynnum and Redlands Youth Suicide Prevention Committee and Bayside Adolescent Boarding Incorporated. These groups, along with the Redlands Health Service Centre and the referral and assessment program, or RAP, are working towards achieving positive solutions for youth in my electorate of Bowman. This group came to me with a list of proposals including better promotion for telephone counselling services, an infocard for all youth in the area, a resource kit for teachers and youth workers and, most importantly, consultation with youth to help them help themselves. This report has gone to many groups in my community in Bowman and we are looking forward to facilitating programs and encouraging the youth to access the services that are provided. The youth of this country are our nation's future. We need to look after them. We need to help them the way we were helped as we grew up. We must remember that the pressures of today's world are in many cases greater than they were for us as teens. We must be sympathetic to their problems, not judgmental. I congratulate the committee, I was pleased to be part of this inquiry and I commend this report to the House. Ms ELLIS (Namadgi) (12.41 p.m.)-I also was part of this House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs and participated in the seminar on youth suicide. I was very pleased to speak at the time of the tabling of the report and am equally pleased to have the opportunity to further add to the discussion today. The benefit for me in coming back into the debate at this point of time is the time that I have had since the issuing of that report to hold discussions, both formally and informally, with a range of people throughout my community on the subject of youth suicide. That is not to say that that had not been spoken of before, but the report has really jolted a lot of people into concentrating on it more and thinking more deeply about what we should, in fact, be trying to do to address this problem. As a member of this committee, I took advantage of getting in excess of 100 copies of that report and I sent copies to a very broad range of people within my electorate. I asked them to look at it, read it, and come back to me with comments. And the comments have been very interesting and useful. 7938 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 There is absolutely no doubt that youth suicide is a serious concern for all of us, not only as parliamentarians, as members of particular political parties, but also as members of our community. Our community, holistically, collectively, has to start to address this problem as seriously as possible. However, we have got to keep the issue in perspective and face up to it with a certain degree of reality. We have also got to admit that it is not unique to this country. In fact, only last weekend or so I read in one of the weekend newspapers a very large article about the very issue we are talking of. It was a newspaper from Bangkok-the main daily major up therethat a friend had given me to read over the weekend. The very subject of youth suicide was being talked about there, and there was a very large article in the paper about how their society is coming to grips with it and what sorts of things they are starting to consider to address the issue. So when we are talking about youth suicide, we need not necessarily get carried away with the Australianism of it, but focus on the problem itself. It certainly knows no borders in terms of ethnic or social bordering and it crosses over a range of people within our community. There is no doubt that the suggestions coming forth in the committee's paper are important and I, along with probably every member of the House, am sincerely looking forward to government action on them. However, I believe that we also need to start looking further into the question of suicide amongst our young and start asking some of the more difficult questions. I think that these relate to the sorts of pressures that are faced by young people today in our society. Have we, as a community, actually thought about how we value our young people? Do we value them enough? Do we value them fairly? Do we put blame on them for difficulties that they may be facing today which are not necessarily of their making at all but are of the making of our generation and generations before us? I am using the word 'blame' in a fairly light fashion. I am not saying that we stand there and throw it at them, but are we inferring it in some of our actions? We are facing the severe and heart breaking problem as a nation of unemployment. This issue is not being dealt with by our nation collectively. I believe it is the country's biggest issue, and one of the most difficult to solve. Should we be blaming our young people if they cannot find employment? Is that what we are doing? I am being very bipartisan in these comments. In some of our actions as a government, as parliamentarians, as business people, as leaders within our community, are we really imputing blame to our young people that is not theirs? Are we considering the impact of those decisions? The pace of change in today's world is already frightening enough to many of us along the road of life. From our point of view, some of our polling in past years has indicated a particular fear, a hesitation or a lack of understanding in the community of the pace of life and the pace of change. A lot of people, both young and old, have difficulty in dealing with that and in keeping up with it. To sound a bit prophetic, when a young person starts out on that road of life, how do we know how these people feel about actually jumping on to that spinning disc of life? Are we actually giving them enough credit to understand the difficulties that they are facing in sorting out their lives in front of them? The age when youth suicide unfortunately occurs is when these decisions have to be faced by these very young people. How on earth can we support them at that time in their lives, given the pace of that spin? Is it their fault that they have trouble in working out where they fit? I sometimes sit and Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7939 wonder how difficult it must be. How often have we all said, 'I wouldn't be young again for all the tea in China, given the difficulties in our world today.' When we talk about youth suicide, we really need to have this broad view about it: what is it and why is it? As a society, another issue that concerns me is our speed to judge. Only a few short years ago-probably in the last three to four years-within my own community, we had an unfortunate period when people were quick to judge groups of young people congregating in the community. There was almost hysteria in the local press at the time so that, if you were not a young person and you saw a group of them in the street, you actually walked around them and avoided them. They were to be feared because they were congregating, loitering-all of these new modem words. Yet what did we do when we were their age? We congregated and we loitered, for want of better terms. I can remember doing it many times on train stations. In today's age of technical advancement, young people spend a lot of time on their own, or with a very small number of people, in front of computer screens or video games and other technology. When on earth are they going to learn to socialise? We have to promote that; we should not condemn them. As a society, we need to sit back and ask whether we are correct in judging in the way that we sometimes do. It is very important to allocate dollars to the question of youth suicide. But as important as that is: what role do those other factors play? Are we giving due credit to considering those other things? Are we sufficiently addressing mental illness amongst the young? I do not believe that we are. In fact, if I hear one more time any government of any colour say, 'We can't afford to do that', I will despair. There are certain things that we simply must afford to do. We cannot let our young people down, nor any part of our community for that matter, when we talk about 'need of home'. Homelessness cannot be addressed without spending money. Mental illness cannot be cured, assisted or supported without spending money. This is an undoubtable fact. While we create buckets of goodwill in terms of money towards youth suicide-which I do not for one moment denigrate-that on its own is not going to achieve a thing, if at the same time we have mentally ill, homeless young people roaming the streets with no support and no hope for their future. Without this holistic approach, we are really cheating our young people and putting ourselves under a delusion. Youth suicide knows no boundary, social or economic. You can have a youth successfully suicide from one of what we would judge to be the best or the worse of families, depending on how you make that judgment. You can have youths successfully suicide whether they go to church every weekend or whether they do not. You can have youths successfully suicide whether or not they have been in the child-care system or whether or not they have had a parent home at 5 o'clock every day. We have to get away from the categorisation of blame. We have to look at all of the underlying reasons why pressures upon our young people are driving them to this terrible choice. One of the things that frustrated me as a member of this committee, and I have said this before and I will say it again, is that whilst there is a lot of data around, it is not comprehensive. It is not good enough to tell me, as a parliamentarian and a decision maker, hopefully, that young men in rural areas succeed in suicide more than others-without telling me why, and we do not know why. Nobody has told me whether the young men in rural areas committing suicide are doing it because their parents' farm has been repossessed, or because they are homosexual and terrified to tell anybody, or because their girlfriend has walked out 7940 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 September 1997 on them. All we know is, and I am being terribly general here, that young rural men suicide successfully more often. The other thing that we need to consider carefully is the fact that 60 per cent of those who succeed in suicide have attempted it before. If we know that, why are we letting that 60 per cent group do it successfully the second, third, fourth or fifth time? What is wrong with the counselling service? What is wrong with the follow up? What is wrong with the collation of data around that individual? Just after this report was tabled I had a lady from my electorate come to see me. This is a family with a lot of socioeconomic problems, a lot of pressures on the single parent. She had had two daughters. The elder daughter succeeded in suicide a few short years ago. The younger daughter, a month or two before the mother came to see me, had also attempted suicide, but had not succeeded. A mad, frantic phone call to the authorities had someone visit her that day to intervene immediately, but the follow-up counselling was 3V2 weeks later. That is just not good enough. In a lot of cases, in 3V2 weeks time a young person may not remember why they did it. Who knows the understandings of a confused young mind? I am not being critical of government when I say that. We have to demand that resources be put where they are required, and I do not think it is good enough for a family in that situation to be forced to wait that period of time. There should be an automatic scooping up of that family, and they should understand immediately that whatever support is required around them is there. The mother was as much in trauma as the daughter. The mother got no assistance, and none was offered. I am sure that this is not a unique situation; I am sure that it happens in many electorates around the country. If we are going to be sincere about this then I really think we need to start making these sorts of demands. Another reaction that has come to me from my community has been the need to demystify youth suicide because in some ways we are too scared to talk about it. If we talk about it too much we might put it up as a pretty good option. The people who have been talking to meparents, members of the clergy, young people-have all said we need to get down to tintacks here. If youth depression is a problem then we need to understand how to recognise it and how to deal with it. As a result of those discussions, I am organising a forum on Friday of next week and Professor Kosky, who was one of the experts who came to our committee, has agreed to come over from Adelaide for this two-hour seminar. I am getting up to 200 people to come to this forum. In fact, we are going to have to close the door. The reason why I am doing this is because the community demands that I give them an opportunity to hear a clinician, in very non-clinician terms, say what it is we are talking about when we talk about youth suicide. I have a lot of faith in this seminar because everyone can come-youth workers, parents, teachers, the clergy, young people, scoutmasters or whoever. The reason for this is that I think these people need to be able to sit down at that level, hear the expert, discuss it with him, and amongst themselves, and go out, I believe, better armed, better informed and more confident in understanding what they are dealing with. This forum is only a very small thing that I can do. The bottom line for me in this whole subject is the consistency we require in approaching the subject. The Here for Life program did a lot of good. The current government's program is going to do a lot of good. But while young people remain homeless, suffering mental illness, unemployed, lacking direction in their future, lacking Thursday, 4 September 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7941 security and knowing where they are going and why, all of those dollars will only have half value. My message to this parliament is that we all should do what we can to make sure that all of those issues are addressed, right across the board, and not isolate youth suicide as some unique part of social policy. It is the result of a lacking in all of those major areas of policy generally. Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile) adjourned.
